20110119010044.000|20110119010047.000|TR0|choreographed, with lots of polite smiles

20110119010956.000|20110119010959.000|TR0|LINE":  All right, this is what it means.  
20110119010959.000|20110119011001.000|TR0|The last three decades, China has 
20110119011001.000|20110119011003.000|TR0|transformed itself into an economic 
20110119011003.000|20110119011006.000|TR0|powerhouse.  It's growing on average 10 
20110119011006.000|20110119011008.000|TR0|percent a year, while the U.S. slowly 
20110119011008.000|20110119011011.000|TR0|shakes off the great recession, growing at 
20110119011011.000|20110119011013.000|TR0|around 2.6 percent.  The U.S. is still the 
20110119011013.000|20110119011015.000|TR0|economic superpower.  Ed Henry is right.  
20110119011015.000|20110119011018.000|TR0|China's economy is just one third the size 
20110119011018.000|20110119011020.000|TR0|of the U.S.
20110119011020.000|20110119011022.000|TR0|
20110119011022.000|20110119011025.000|TR0|But China's population is some four times 
20110119011025.000|20110119011027.000|TR0|bigger, that population one of the reasons 
20110119011027.000|20110119011030.000|TR0|China has become the factory floor to the

20110119014200.000|20110119014202.000|TR0|daughter, Eunice, and served as a campaign 
20110119014202.000|20110119014205.000|TR0|manager for her brother Jack's 
20110119014205.000|20110119014207.000|TR0|presidential run in 1960.
20110119014207.000|20110119014210.000|TR0|
20110119014210.000|20110119014212.000|TR0|SPITZER:  When Martin Luther King was 
20110119014212.000|20110119014214.000|TR0|jailed in Georgia, it was Shriver, a 
20110119014214.000|20110119014217.000|TR0|champion of civil rights in Chicago who 
20110119014217.000|20110119014219.000|TR0|convinced the young candidate to phone 
20110119014219.000|20110119014221.000|TR0|King's wife to offer support.  After JFK 
20110119014221.000|20110119014224.000|TR0|was elected, he gave Shriver a new job, 
20110119014224.000|20110119014226.000|TR0|launching the Peace Corps, a volunteer 
20110119014226.000|20110119014228.000|TR0|organization dedicated to peace around the 
20110119014228.000|20110119014231.000|TR0|globe.
20110119014231.000|20110119014233.000|TR0|
20110119014233.000|20110119014236.000|TR0|He served as Richard Nixon's ambassador to 
20110119014236.000|20110119014238.000|TR0|France.  And then in 1972 was tapped by 
20110119014238.000|20110119014240.000|TR0|presidential candidate George McGovern as 
20110119014240.000|20110119014243.000|TR0|his running mate against Nixon.  In 1994, 
20110119014243.000|20110119014245.000|TR0|President Clinton awarded Shriver the 
20110119014245.000|20110119014247.000|TR0|Medal of Freedom.
20110119014247.000|20110119014250.000|TR0|
20110119014250.000|20110119014252.000|TR0|PARKER:  In recent years when he was 
20110119014252.000|20110119014255.000|TR0|diagnosed with Alzheimer's, Shriver's 
20110119014255.000|20110119014257.000|TR0|daughter, Maria, made it her personal 
20110119014257.000|20110119014259.000|TR0|cause.  He died surrounded by his family.  
20110119014259.000|20110119014302.000|TR0|In a statement, they said Sargent Shriver, 
20110119014302.000|20110119014304.000|TR0|quote, "lived to make the world a more 
20110119014304.000|20110119014306.000|TR0|joyful, faithful and compassionate place.  
20110119014306.000|20110119014309.000|TR0|We pray that his spirit and example will 
20110119014309.000|20110119014311.000|TR0|guide us as we accept the challenge of 
20110119014311.000|20110119014313.000|TR0|living as he did."

20110119014316.000|20110119014318.000|TR0|We'll be right back.

20110119014323.000|20110119014325.000|TR0|Hill today, House Republicans move one 
20110119014325.000|20110119014328.000|TR0|step closer to repealing President Obama's 
20110119014328.000|20110119014330.000|TR0|controversial health care reform.  With 
20110119014330.000|20110119014332.000|TR0|the vote scheduled for tomorrow, GOP 
20110119014332.000|20110119014335.000|TR0|critics continue to blast the bill as, 
20110119014335.000|20110119014337.000|TR0|quote, "job stifling and cost increasing." 
20110119014337.000|20110119014340.000|TR0|Of course, how to pay for health care in 
20110119014340.000|20110119014342.000|TR0|any form has legislators on both sides of

20110119014351.000|20110119014354.000|TR0|could be responsible for up to 30 percent 
20110119014354.000|20110119014356.000|TR0|of health care costs.
20110119014356.000|20110119014359.000|TR0|

20110119014401.000|20110119014403.000|TR0|at "The New Yorker" magazine.  His article 
20110119014403.000|20110119014406.000|TR0|in this week's issue details a 
20110119014406.000|20110119014408.000|TR0|revolutionary approach to slashing medical 
20110119014408.000|20110119014410.000|TR0|costs.
20110119014410.000|20110119014413.000|TR0|
20110119014413.000|20110119014415.000|TR0|Dr. Gawande, welcome.
20110119014415.000|20110119014417.000|TR0|

20110119014420.000|20110119014422.000|TR0|WRITER:  Thank you for having me on.
20110119014422.000|20110119014425.000|TR0|
20110119014425.000|20110119014427.000|TR0|PARKER:  That's a great article.  
20110119014427.000|20110119014429.000|TR0|Fascinating.  You describe a situation 
20110119014429.000|20110119014432.000|TR0|where a small percentage of patients 
20110119014432.000|20110119014434.000|TR0|consuming enormous amount of resources and 
20110119014434.000|20110119014436.000|TR0|you used Camden, New Jersey, as an 
20110119014436.000|20110119014439.000|TR0|example. Describe how that can happen.
20110119014439.000|20110119014441.000|TR0|
20110119014441.000|20110119014444.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  Yes, it's true everywhere across 
20110119014444.000|20110119014446.000|TR0|the country that health care costs tend to 
20110119014446.000|20110119014448.000|TR0|be in hot spots.  One percent of the 
20110119014448.000|20110119014451.000|TR0|population accounts for 30 percent of 
20110119014451.000|20110119014453.000|TR0|health care costs and that's true in 
20110119014453.000|20110119014455.000|TR0|almost every one of our communities.  Five 
20110119014455.000|20110119014458.000|TR0|percent account for 60 percent of the 
20110119014458.000|20110119014500.000|TR0|costs, which is to say that the sickest 
20110119014500.000|20110119014502.000|TR0|people are the ones who use the most 
20110119014502.000|20110119014505.000|TR0|resources.
20110119014505.000|20110119014507.000|TR0|
20110119014507.000|20110119014510.000|TR0|PARKER:  So how bad can it get?  What kind 
20110119014510.000|20110119014512.000|TR0|of medical bills can just one individual 
20110119014512.000|20110119014514.000|TR0|bill rack up in a year, just as an example?
20110119014514.000|20110119014517.000|TR0|
20110119014517.000|20110119014519.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  So I tell the story of a family 
20110119014519.000|20110119014521.000|TR0|physician who started looking into this in 
20110119014521.000|20110119014524.000|TR0|Camden, New Jersey.  And he found the most 
20110119014524.000|20110119014526.000|TR0|expensive patient there in their community 
20110119014526.000|20110119014529.000|TR0|had cost $3.5 million over the course of 
20110119014529.000|20110119014531.000|TR0|about five years.
20110119014531.000|20110119014533.000|TR0|
20110119014533.000|20110119014536.000|TR0|PARKER:  Wow.
20110119014536.000|20110119014538.000|TR0|
20110119014538.000|20110119014540.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Well, Doctor, as you said, this 
20110119014540.000|20110119014543.000|TR0|is -- your diagnosis is accurate across 
20110119014543.000|20110119014545.000|TR0|the entire medical delivery system where 
20110119014545.000|20110119014547.000|TR0|people with multiple diagnoses are the 
20110119014547.000|20110119014550.000|TR0|ones responsible for this enormous 
20110119014550.000|20110119014552.000|TR0|percentage of the cost.  So what is the 
20110119014552.000|20110119014555.000|TR0|answer from a cost delivery perspective as 
20110119014555.000|20110119014557.000|TR0|somebody who's both a doctor?  And as you 
20110119014557.000|20110119014559.000|TR0|obviously are worried about cost, what do 
20110119014559.000|20110119014602.000|TR0|you do to confront this?
20110119014602.000|20110119014604.000|TR0|
20110119014604.000|20110119014606.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  Yes.  I mean, I had it as much 
20110119014606.000|20110119014609.000|TR0|of a puzzle as anybody else had.  But what 
20110119014609.000|20110119014611.000|TR0|I started looking for is what are people 
20110119014611.000|20110119014614.000|TR0|in communities actually doing where 
20110119014614.000|20110119014616.000|TR0|they're bringing costs down?  And what you 
20110119014616.000|20110119014618.000|TR0|find now over and over in experiments 
20110119014618.000|20110119014621.000|TR0|being seen across the country is people 
20110119014621.000|20110119014623.000|TR0|who are looking at it kind of the way 
20110119014623.000|20110119014625.000|TR0|crime reformers look at it, go to where 
20110119014625.000|20110119014628.000|TR0|the highest crimes are, in this case, go 
20110119014628.000|20110119014630.000|TR0|to where the highest health care costs are 
20110119014630.000|20110119014632.000|TR0|and put your resources there.  So they 
20110119014632.000|20110119014635.000|TR0|worked on lowering the cost of the sickest 
20110119014635.000|20110119014637.000|TR0|people in the population.  And what they 
20110119014637.000|20110119014640.000|TR0|recognize is that the people with the 
20110119014640.000|20110119014642.000|TR0|highest costs, who are in the hospital 
20110119014642.000|20110119014644.000|TR0|months at a time or in and out of 
20110119014644.000|20110119014647.000|TR0|emergency rooms, sometimes hundreds of 
20110119014647.000|20110119014649.000|TR0|times, are getting the worst care.  And 
20110119014649.000|20110119014651.000|TR0|good care can really change not just their 
20110119014651.000|20110119014654.000|TR0|outcomes but improve their lives and lower 
20110119014654.000|20110119014656.000|TR0|their costs.
20110119014656.000|20110119014659.000|TR0|
20110119014659.000|20110119014701.000|TR0|SPITZER:  But what you mean by good care 
20110119014701.000|20110119014703.000|TR0|is not just better result in each 
20110119014703.000|20110119014706.000|TR0|procedure but a much greater process of 
20110119014706.000|20110119014708.000|TR0|intervention by the medical system so that 
20110119014708.000|20110119014710.000|TR0|you have a primary care physician who goes 
20110119014710.000|20110119014713.000|TR0|to them and monitors what they do, make 
20110119014713.000|20110119014715.000|TR0|sure they take their meds, make sure 
20110119014715.000|20110119014718.000|TR0|they're staying on their insulin if that's 
20110119014718.000|20110119014720.000|TR0|the issue.  That type of managed care had 
20110119014720.000|20110119014722.000|TR0|a dramatic impact.  How do you implement 
20110119014722.000|20110119014725.000|TR0|that?
20110119014725.000|20110119014727.000|TR0|
20110119014727.000|20110119014729.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  Yes, I mean, here's the 
20110119014729.000|20110119014732.000|TR0|revolution.  It is places like this 
20110119014732.000|20110119014734.000|TR0|experiment in Camden, New Jersey, by a 
20110119014734.000|20110119014736.000|TR0|doctor or in Atlantic City, New Jersey, or 
20110119014736.000|20110119014739.000|TR0|right here at home where I'm from, Boston, 
20110119014739.000|20110119014741.000|TR0|where what people have done is create 
20110119014741.000|20110119014744.000|TR0|primary care for patients who are only 
20110119014744.000|20110119014746.000|TR0|focusing on those who are the most 
20110119014746.000|20110119014748.000|TR0|expensive and saying our job is figure out 
20110119014748.000|20110119014751.000|TR0|how to reduce the likelihood they'll use 
20110119014751.000|20110119014753.000|TR0|the emergency room, reduce their 
20110119014753.000|20110119014755.000|TR0|likelihood of needing to go to the 
20110119014755.000|20110119014758.000|TR0|hospital.  And that means that you target 
20110119014758.000|20110119014800.000|TR0|if they have coronary artery disease and 
20110119014800.000|20110119014803.000|TR0|diabetes, you work on keeping them on 
20110119014803.000|20110119014805.000|TR0|their drugs, making sure they quit 
20110119014805.000|20110119014807.000|TR0|smoking, being able to catch their 
20110119014807.000|20110119014810.000|TR0|problems that are starting to fester 
20110119014810.000|20110119014812.000|TR0|before it lands them in an emergency room. 
20110119014812.000|20110119014814.000|TR0| And that's not usually what we're 
20110119014814.000|20110119014817.000|TR0|equipped to do as doctors with only 
20110119014817.000|20110119014819.000|TR0|20-minute visits as our main mechanism of 
20110119014819.000|20110119014821.000|TR0|helping people.
20110119014821.000|20110119014824.000|TR0|
20110119014824.000|20110119014826.000|TR0|PARKER:  Well, in so many of the cases you 
20110119014826.000|20110119014829.000|TR0|described, some of the patients who are in 
20110119014829.000|20110119014831.000|TR0|the greatest need were also people who 
20110119014831.000|20110119014833.000|TR0|simply were not capable of taking their 
20110119014833.000|20110119014836.000|TR0|medications in a responsible, consistent 
20110119014836.000|20110119014838.000|TR0|way.  And so part of that intervention 
20110119014838.000|20110119014840.000|TR0|involved in some cases a social worker or 
20110119014840.000|20110119014843.000|TR0|people who were just on call to take 
20110119014843.000|20110119014845.000|TR0|questions and that sort of thing.  How 
20110119014845.000|20110119014848.000|TR0|practical is that?  I mean, can we 
20110119014848.000|20110119014850.000|TR0|nationalize something like that?
20110119014850.000|20110119014852.000|TR0|
20110119014852.000|20110119014855.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  Yes.  I mean, you know, they've 
20110119014855.000|20110119014857.000|TR0|started making it practical.  The thing 
20110119014857.000|20110119014859.000|TR0|is, you know, the problems here defy our 
20110119014859.000|20110119014902.000|TR0|ideologies.  These are patients who do 
20110119014902.000|20110119014904.000|TR0|have behavioral issues.  So, you know, 
20110119014904.000|20110119014906.000|TR0|this doctor, for example, found that those 
20110119014906.000|20110119014909.000|TR0|topmost expensive people, his patient 
20110119014909.000|20110119014911.000|TR0|number one was 560 pounds.  He had alcohol 
20110119014911.000|20110119014914.000|TR0|and smoking and drug use problems.  But he 
20110119014914.000|20110119014916.000|TR0|also had severe congestive heart failure, 
20110119014916.000|20110119014918.000|TR0|need for technologies that would keep him 
20110119014918.000|20110119014921.000|TR0|alive as well as behavior change.  And it 
20110119014921.000|20110119014923.000|TR0|was a team approach, recognizing that just

20110119014925.000|20110119014928.000|TR0|complex patient was going to just mean he

20110119014935.000|20110119014937.000|TR0|Well, three years of work with this 
20110119014937.000|20110119014940.000|TR0|patient, nurses, social workers, meant 
20110119014940.000|20110119014942.000|TR0|that they were able to reduce his cost by 
20110119014942.000|20110119014944.000|TR0|well over 50 percent and make him 
20110119014944.000|20110119014947.000|TR0|healthier.
20110119014947.000|20110119014949.000|TR0|
20110119014949.000|20110119014951.000|TR0|PARKER:  So in reducing that cost, was it 
20110119014951.000|20110119014954.000|TR0|cost-effective when you take into 
20110119014954.000|20110119014956.000|TR0|consideration all the intervention and the

20110119015003.000|20110119015006.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  Yes, it easily could have been 
20110119015006.000|20110119015008.000|TR0|that you spent just as much effort and it 
20110119015008.000|20110119015010.000|TR0|takes more medications and it was not cost 
20110119015010.000|20110119015013.000|TR0|effective.  But now, they've shown in 
20110119015013.000|20110119015015.000|TR0|multiple efforts now that they are able to 
20110119015015.000|20110119015018.000|TR0|make it cost effective.
20110119015018.000|20110119015020.000|TR0|
20110119015020.000|20110119015022.000|TR0|A program in Atlantic City with the casino 
20110119015022.000|20110119015025.000|TR0|workers union and the hospital ended up 
20110119015025.000|20110119015027.000|TR0|for a group of about 1,200 patients who 
20110119015027.000|20110119015029.000|TR0|represented the top five percent of the 
20110119015029.000|20110119015032.000|TR0|people in that union.  Their costs were 
20110119015032.000|20110119015034.000|TR0|able to lower 20 percent, including taking 
20110119015034.000|20110119015037.000|TR0|into account all of the extra care they 
20110119015037.000|20110119015039.000|TR0|were getting.  Their focus was on keeping 
20110119015039.000|20110119015041.000|TR0|them out of the hospital, keeping them 
20110119015041.000|20110119015044.000|TR0|healthy enough to get better and better. 
20110119015044.000|20110119015046.000|TR0|They lowered their smoking rate 60 
20110119015046.000|20110119015048.000|TR0|percent, but they also made sure that they 
20110119015048.000|20110119015051.000|TR0|took their medications and got proper care 
20110119015051.000|20110119015053.000|TR0|when they needed it.
20110119015053.000|20110119015055.000|TR0|
20110119015055.000|20110119015058.000|TR0|SPITZER:  To bring your conclusions back 
20110119015058.000|20110119015100.000|TR0|to the current bill or the bill that was 
20110119015100.000|20110119015103.000|TR0|passed by Congress last year, does that 
20110119015103.000|20110119015105.000|TR0|bill create pilot programs to try what 
20110119015105.000|20110119015107.000|TR0|you're describing in communities around 
20110119015107.000|20110119015110.000|TR0|the nation?
20110119015110.000|20110119015112.000|TR0|
20110119015112.000|20110119015114.000|TR0|GAWANDE:  Yes.  You know, the way to think 
20110119015114.000|20110119015117.000|TR0|about it is, did the bill say, OK, this 
20110119015117.000|20110119015119.000|TR0|has to deploy?  You know, top down 
20110119015119.000|20110119015122.000|TR0|Washington says, every community has to do 
20110119015122.000|20110119015124.000|TR0|it exactly this way?  The answer is no. 
20110119015124.000|20110119015126.000|TR0|These are innovators on the edges who are 
20110119015126.000|20110119015129.000|TR0|creating brand-new ways of providing 
20110119015129.000|20110119015131.000|TR0|medical care that's better than our 
20110119015131.000|20110119015133.000|TR0|current health system. The bill provides 
20110119015133.000|20110119015136.000|TR0|billions in incentives so that these 
20110119015136.000|20110119015138.000|TR0|doctors who I mostly describe are almost 
20110119015138.000|20110119015140.000|TR0|saints.  They're altruists who haven't 
20110119015140.000|20110119015143.000|TR0|been paid to do this kind of work but now 
20110119015143.000|20110119015145.000|TR0|are seeing incentives in legislation that 
20110119015145.000|20110119015148.000|TR0|starts to turn that around so that you can 
20110119015148.000|20110119015150.000|TR0|imagine whole communities of doctors who 
20110119015150.000|20110119015152.000|TR0|get really, really good at this.
20110119015152.000|20110119015155.000|TR0|
20110119015155.000|20110119015157.000|TR0|SPITZER:  All right.  Dr. Gawande, thanks 
20110119015157.000|20110119015159.000|TR0|so much.  A hugely important insight.  It 
20110119015159.000|20110119015202.000|TR0|is exactly what we saw in New York and 
20110119015202.000|20110119015204.000|TR0|we're trying to figure out where all New 
20110119015204.000|20110119015207.000|TR0|York State's Medicaid dollars were going.  
20110119015207.000|20110119015209.000|TR0|So thank you so much.

20110119015252.000|20110119015254.000|TR0|president of the Asia Society.  Jamie will
